awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Noah M. Arbesfeld is " The representation-theoretic and combinatorial structure of moduli spaces of sheaves". The host institution for the fellowship is Imperial College, London, UK and the sponsoring scientist is Richard Thomas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many important calculations in mathematical physics can be expressed in terms of intersection theory on algebro-geometric moduli spaces. A key example of such a moduli space is the Hilbert scheme of points on a surface, which parametrizes configurations of points on an algebraic surface. 

The project's outcomes concern Hilbert schemes and their higher-rank generalizations called Quot schemes. The geometry of such spaces is often complicated, but can be probed using natural classes called tautological classes. For example, integrals of tautological classes on Hilbert schemes can display rich structure when the underlying surface is fixed but the number of points being parametrized varies. 

The project's main results explicate the structure of generating series formed from tautological classes on Hilbert schemes and Quot schemes. Tautological classes on Hilbert and Quot schemes arise in computations in enumerative algebraic geometry and have connections to many other subfields of mathematics, including the representation theory of infinite-dimensional Lie algebras and the combinatorics of partitions and symmetric functions. Such classes also appear in physics, for example as matter in mathematical approaches to supersymmetric gauge theories.

Quot schemes are generally not smooth. However, for Quot schemes on surfaces parametrizing quotients of dimension at most 1, well-behaved invariants can be defined in terms of their virtual fundamental class, a replacement for the ordinary fundamental class. In previous work, many generating series formed from tautological integrals for Quot schemes on surfaces were shown to be expansions of rational functions. Work of the PI with D. Johnson, W. Lim, D. Oprea and R. Pandharipande demonstrated analogs of these results when the virtual fundamental class is replaced by the virtual structure sheaf, its K-theoretic counterpart. Namely, we showed that many examples of so-called virtual K-theoretic descendent series are expansions of rational functions. In contrast, we showed that the virtual cobordism series of such Quot schemes need not be rational. We also formulated and proved two new symmetries for generating series of tautological integrals for Quot schemes on surfaces. One, called Segre-Verlinde duality, is a simplified version of a more intricate prediction for tautological classes on Hilbert schemes of points. The other duality is new and admits no obvious analog for Hilbert schemes. These results have influenced subsequent studies of tautological classes of other Quot schemes, including those parametrizing quotients on curves and 4-folds. 

The project also produced results for analogous series for Hilbert schemes of points on surfaces, regarded as smooth varieties. Using the combinatorics of Macdonald polynomials, the PI showed that K-theoretic descendent series are rational functions, and can in particular be written as generating series whose coefficients are given by a polynomial. The techniques also enable the computation of any fixed descendent series. As a consequence, formulas for new descendent series were obtained, along with new proofs of previously known results. The behavior of K-theoretic descendent series for Hilbert schemes contrasts with expectations for previously studied analogs in cohomology. Such cohomological descendent series are conjectured to belong to a certain algebra of q-series called q-multiple zeta values.

During the fellowship period, the PI supervised 2 masters students working on projects related to the subjects of the fellowship and co-organized a special session at the Joint Mathematics Meetings.
